properties.grant_description: The Western Pennsylvania Environmental Awards Program recognizes and honors outstanding achievements of organizations, programs, and individuals in a wide range of environmental initiatives throughout the region. The Western Pennsylvania Watershed Program is a 2005 finalist.

This workshop is entitled "Avoiding Potholes in the Non-Profit Fastlane" and is designed to delve deeper into board development, understanding and writing financial statements, general liability, and directors' and officers' insurance.
The purpose of this grant will support the National Governors' Association Summer meeting involving the Federal Abandoned Mine Lands Program.

The Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay (Alliance), Center for Watershed Protection, and the National Association of Home Builders have formed a partnership known as the Builders for the Bay to address local development reform. The Builders for the Bay partnership utilizes a cost-effective and innovative model called the local site planning roundtable. This model deals directly with the local development process including: the codes and ordinances, the approval process, and design review related to environmentally sensitive development practices. The Alliance proposes to conduct a site planning roundtable in the Altoona region of Blair County.

An abandoned mine discharge is impacting the headwaters of Chest Creek at the Bakerton Sportsman’s Club. The proposed treatment system will be comprised of an Open Limestone Bed and will be capable of treating the maximum flow of 50 GPM. The project is intended to not only clean this discharge but also serve as a demonstration project illustrating AMD mitigation.

Cowanshannock Creek Watershed Association aims to treat entrenched streams and their associated flooding problems on Cowanshannock Creek. Because of its proximity to the Junior/Senior High School, this project will also serve as a valuable classroom for understanding natural stream channel design and will assist the student in using scientific methods in evaluating the project's ecological benefits. The project will include: the removal of large quantities of sediment, reconfiguring the stream and adding meanders, developing overhangs and other habitat structures, and restore the natural flood plain.

The goal of this stream bank rehabilitation demonstration project is to create a low-maintenance, self-sustaining urban stream corridor. This newly created area of greenway/open space along Cove Creek will serve as a demonstration area to highlight innovative solution in urban riparian management and it is anticipated that this project will also serve as only the first phase of a larger public greenway plan for Cove Creek south of Old Route 30.
properties.project_name: Big Cove Crk Rest.Nat.Stream Channel Design

properties.grant_description: This proposal is aimed at determining if the Upper and Lower Kittanning coal seams are connected at the Point in Johnstown. The gathered information will be used to assess the potential for capping the discharge at its current point of emanation and redirecting the water to a more favorable location for treatment.
properties.project_name: AMD Watershed assessment of ext mine pools

properties.grant_description: Years of water quality data has been collected and analyzed along Shamokin Creek and is available to any interested party. The Shamokin Creek Restoration Alliance is interested in making this data even more valuable by installing four steel weirs and five transducers which will provide accurate flow measurements as well as water quality data.

The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy (SAC) would like to explore opportunities to further the findings of Damariscotta’s Resource Recovery III pilot project for manganese recovery. The pilot project proved that Damariscotta’s technology could extract industrial grade manganese from abandoned mine drainage. SAC hopes to expand the project by creating a business plan for this viable recovery technology.

The Lowber Discharge pollutes more than 2 miles of Sewickley Creek and contributes more than 1M lbs. of iron oxide loading to the receiving stream annually. Visual signs of this pollution are evident in the orange staining that can be seen along the downstream, eastern shores of the Youghiogheny for upward of 5 miles. The Sewickley Creek Watershed Association proposes to create a passive treatment system to capture the iron and sell it as commercial-grade pigment.

Available data suggests that streams impacted by Abandoned Mine Drainage (AMD) are not able to effectively process pollutants. Consequently, watersheds impacted by AMD are exporting disproportionate amounts of nutrients and pollutants to the Chesapeake Bay. This is only a hypothesis because past AMD studies have seldom included impacts on streams. But if true, then AMD mitigation in small streams will provide a double benefit: it will restore stream health locally and reduce the export of nutrients in to the region’s larger rivers and the Chesapeake Bay. Stroud proposes to test their hypothesis on stream in the West Branch Susquehanna River over a two-year period.

The Mercer County Conservation District completed a Fox Run watershed assessment and determined that there were three primary AMD impacts in the watershed. All three were determined to be ‘treatable’ with passive technologies. This project is Phase I in abating the impacts of AMD in the watershed.

The Turtle Creek Watershed Association is interested in mitigating the impacts of the Irwin Discharge as well as the possible incorporation of the Delmont and Export Discharges in this system. The Irwin Discharge is responsible for contaminating 8 miles of stream. Hedin Environmental determined that both active and passive treatments of the discharge at the site were not feasible. However if the discharge was to be piped 9000 feet downstream, there is an area large enough to construct the 60 acres of wetlands and ponds necessary to mitigate the discharge. Further study is required to determine whether this site could support the treatment of the Delmont and Export Discharges.

The PA Association of Conservation Districts is a partner in the reauthorization of the Abandoned Mine Land Fund. They are involved locally and know the location and impacts of the most degrading sites. They are also the broker for agricultural conservation which utilizes cover crops and no-till planting for preserving topsoil and keeping it out of our waterways.
The Friends of Raystown Lake would like to benefit from the help of an AmeriCorps member to support important environmental improvement projects.

The mission of the Pennsylvania Biodiversity Partnership is to conserve biodiversity statewide, including all of Pennsylvania's watersheds, by promoting coordination and communication among our members. Sponsorship of the Pennsylvania Biodiversity Conservation Plan will help facilitate the first comprehensive statewide plan for biodiversity in the Commonwealth.

In an effort to seek greater efficiency and sustainability, the Pennsylvania Organization for Watersheds and Rivers has proposed merging with the Pennsylvania Land Trust. Preliminary discussions have been held between both boards of directors, each of whom has agreed to explore the possibility of joining forces. This grant would facilitate further meetings regarding this issue.
This grant will pay for updating grant information on the POWR website.

The mission of WVIA (public television and radio) is to inform and educate the citizens of Northeastern Pennsylvania and the Central Susquehanna Valley and promote this region. This mission is the basis of the documentary, "Looking to the River."
properties.project_name: Sponsorship to Sus Riv doc."Looking to the River"

properties.grant_description: The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy will provide technical support and related program administrative services through its Project Manager to the Western Pennsylvania Watershed Program (WPWP) in the amount of 16 hours per week plus mileage for a service provider.
properties.project_description: SAC provided access to their Project Manager to assist then Western PA Watershed Program with project implementation.

properties.grant_description: Storm water best management practices are essential in reducing urban runoff and subsequent flooding. This project will use permeable surfaces, detention ponds, filter strips, riparian planting, bioswales, greenroofs, infiltrator pipes, raingardens, vegetated wet ponds, and other means to slow storm runoff allowing the water to percolate. This will not only assist in reducing flood hazards, but also enhance green space, promote enhanced water quality, and provide a more cost-effective solution to traditional storm water conveyance systems.

The French Creek Project (FCP) is seeking funding for a continuation of their site-specific restoration work in this important watershed. The FCP has recently changed leadership and has completed a Strategic Plan which coincides with their 10 year anniversary. The areas of focus remain the same; science, conservation, and outreach/education.
properties.project_name: Continued support of cons.work in French Crk Watershed

properties.sponsor_name: Merrill W. Linn Land & Waterways Conservancy
properties.project_benefits: This is an innovative design to address atmospheric acid deposition. This would be a new direction for the Program and watershed management in the state. Until old grandfathered coal fired plants are regulated, acid deposition will continue to be a non-point source of pollution.
properties.grant_description: Buffalo Creek watershed is 303d listed for acid deposition impairment. Acidity within the watershed has led to the development of a TMDL for the watershed. The TMDL encourages reduction of acidity to promote biological recovery in the watershed. The uppermost 7 miles of the watershed are severely impacted by acid deposition and is largely devoid of aquatic organisms. The Dietz Consulting Group plans to design and construct an aerobic limestone basin and an aerobic vertical flow wetland, adding alkalinity to the upper reaches of Buffalo Creek.

Invasive plants are becoming an increasing problem throughout the nation. As importation of flora and fauna occur and as species are introduced inadvertently through transportation of goods, native species are under attack. People throughout the country need to be educated on the impacts of introducing invasive plants. Invasive species are often sought out for their vibrant colors or ornamental characteristics. Often, these plants have no native enemies which allow them to proliferate quickly and dominate native plant species. This project would increase education and outreach concerning stewardship of native planting areas and facilitate removal of invasive species. Friends of the Riverfront will also implement 15 major plantings and will provide follow-up site maintenance.
properties.project_benefits: Educating the general public on the risks of planting non-native species will potentially limit the introduction of invasive plants.

properties.grant_description: Development in the watershed has impacted the natural flooding sequence. Impervious surfaces, development runoff, and the expansion of highway systems are contributing rapid runoff to Raredon Run. An 8.5 acre mitigated wetland will be constructed in the upper reaches of the watershed as part of the permitting for the PA Turnpike Commission’s South Beltway, Findlay Connector Project. This wetland will help to moderate stormwater runoff, regulating both flow and flood frequency. Independence Marsh Foundation has outlined a plan to evaluate flood damage and increased incidents of flooding along Raredon Run. This plan outlines four specific reaches requiring natural stream channel design and riparian restoration.
properties.project_benefits: Educating the general public on the risks of planting non-native species will potentially limit the introduction of invasive plants.

properties.grant_description: The Upper Saxman Run Discharge is the largest AMD impact to the watershed. The Loyalhanna Watershed plans to capture this discharge in a transmission line to the Latrobe Sewage Plant. The headpressure created by the differential elevation of the discharge and the sewage plant coupled with the flowing water will be used to power a microturbine which will be used to generate 1/6th of the electricity needed for the Active Iron Sludge – Sequencing Batch Reactor (Reactor). This active treatment system, developed by Dietz et al, has been operating at the plant for over two years. Designs are underway to enlarge the Reactor to accommodate the treatment of the Upper Saxman Run Discharge and two other discharges. This project represents a new technology that could lead to a changing paradigm in AMD treatment.
properties.project_benefits: Once this treatment facility is fully expanded and online, there will be an overall reduction of 638 tons of annual iron loading.

properties.grant_description: The Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition for Environmental Studies includes a group of seven regional colleges and universities engaged in collaborative environmental projects within the Mid-Susquehanna River Watershed. This application supports the work of these efforts by involving additional faculty and students in summer research. The colleges in the Susquehanna River Heartland include Bloomsburg, Bucknell, Kings, Lock Haven, Lycoming, and Susquehanna.

This site is an integral part of the Indian Creek rehabilitation effort. Marsolino-Leighty is actually comprised of three discharges that impact Newmyer Run rendering it unsuitable for aquatic life. Newmyer Run then enters Poplar Run depositing so much aluminum that it turns the water milky white. Poplar Run enters Indian Creek downstream of the Kalp Discharge. MWA is attempting to secure funding for property acquisition at this site, which also includes easement for the perpetual use of an existing 2500 lineal foot access road and associated stream crossing. Resolution of the land acquisition issue is necessary to the implementation of this project and to the comprehensive restoration of Indian Creek.

Working from illegal dump surveys, PA Cleanways looks to start up four new county chapters to address the non-point pollution and unsightly mess created stream-side by illegal dumping. Target areas will include Northumberland, Dauphin, Columbia, and Luzerne and Western Schuykill Counties. Start-up activities include public education efforts, illegal dump cleanups that directly involve and engage volunteers, and ongoing training and technical assistance to community members on PA Cleanways program implementation in their local communities. Under new leadership, PA Cleanways is very well respected and well organized to achieve their goals. The most significant use of funding for start-up chapters pertains to the insurance that is secured for clean-up activities.

properties.grant_name: Aerway Aerator Farmer Replication Demonstration Project
properties.project_benefits: This program has had a history of working on agricultural Best Management Practices, primarily through Project Grass, which demonstrates and implements rotational grazing systems to cut down on non-point source pollution. While there are many impacts to these watersheds, this type of demonstration project added to the tool box of practices will help cut back on non-point pollution.
properties.grant_description: Nutrient Management Specialist and Agricultural Conservation Technician, Lynn Vozniak has worked extensively with farmers to enhance Allegheny and Beaver Counties’ No-till Program. Through her efforts she became aware of a need to restore and reconstitute degraded pasture lands without turning-over the land. An Aerway Aerator is added to a manure spreader and injects the manure into the substrate, substantially reducing the chances of manure runoff and significantly increasing plant nutrient uptake. Penn State University agreed to help evaluate the beneficial impact of the unit.

Pennsylvania Environmental Council (PEC) looks to advance their agricultural, stormwater, conservation partnership, and education work in the Northern Allegheny region, including the French Creek Project’s work in the French Creek watershed. Work remains to be done as identified through an intensive one-year strategic planning process undertaken by the French Creek Project and its partners throughout 2005.

A passive treatment system designed by NA Water Systems will be installed to treat several diffuse seeps emanating from Clinton Road (Allegheny County Airport Authority property) that degrade the West Fork of Enlow Run, which then flows into and consequently impacts Montour Run. The system will consist of an anoxic collection system and a vertical flow pond.
properties.project_benefits: Completion of this project is expected to eliminate 46,000 pounds of acidity, 700 pounds of iron, and 5,000 pounds of aluminum from the West Fork of Enlow Run per year. The final effluent from the system is expected to be pH6.
properties.project_name: Clinton Rd Acid Mine Drainage Remediation System

properties.grant_description: The Blue Valley AMD treatment facility was built to address AMD impacts in the watershed. With the closing of Big Spring Fish Culture Station and increased regulations on fish culture stations, the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission (PA F&B) is facing potential fingerling shortfall. This project would utilize AMD mitigated water to culture fish, using recirculation aquaculture system. The Blue Valley Fish Culture Station is a first-of-its-kind fish culture station. The facility not only is the first to use AMD treated water but is also the only PA F&B fish culture station with RAS technology.
properties.project_benefits: Distribution of fish hatcheries is a good, common sense concept. Utilizing a restored water resource is also a good idea. Elimination of chemical treatment with passive means is not only a benefit to the environment but working in the direction of sustainability of the project.

properties.grant_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team focuses its attention on two primary programs – Water Monitoring and Environmental Education. Through the Water Monitoring Program the Stream Team provides technical assistance to smaller watershed associations, county conservation districts, and similar organizations. The Stream Team has also trained over 40 citizen volunteers and, together collected nearly 600 water samples from numerous abandoned mine discharges, twelve AMD treatment systems, and several streams impacted by AMD.

The objectives of this planning program are to foster a greater public understanding of watershed characteristics as they affect coldwater ecosystems and produce preliminary resource planning to documents that may lead to full river conservation plans or direct implementation to protect and enhance our coldwater fisheries. This year's awards will support Coldwater Conservation Plans for Bushkill Creek (Northampton County), Canoe Run (Cameron County), Cold Run (Schuylkill County), Fry's Run (Northampton County), Middle Creek (Adams County), Plum Creek (Blair County), Roaring Creek (Columbia County), Tubmill Creek (Centre County), and Wallace Run (Centre County).

The purpose of the Chesapeake Watershed Forum is to provide an annual opportunity for watershed organizations and local government officials from around the multi-state Bay region to learn the latest scientific techniques in Bay restoration and protection, address specific organizational capacity building needs, focus on regional and watershed-wide needs, network with other watershed organizations, and enjoy the beauty of the watershed. Upon taking part in this conference, watershed groups and local governments will have more resources and a reinvigorated drive to implement more restoration activities in their respective watersheds.

This grant will support “A strategic approach to public/private partnership projects that improve the delivery of technical assistance to farmers in support of State Tributary Strategy Implementation in the Chesapeake Bay.” This Center for Agriculture Partnerships project is a cooperative effort with the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science and the Chesapeake Bay Funders’ Network to identify and create strategic opportunities that reduce the environmental impacts of agricultural operations in key areas of the Chesapeake Bay. The overall goal of this effort is to organize field based partnership projects that increase the use of innovative agricultural technical delivery systems for the Chesapeake Bay. Through these partnerships, methods will be demonstrated and validated for organizing efforts, providing technical support, and creating capacity for a change that can be replicated widely in the Chesapeake Bay. These areas of pollution or "hotspots" have been identified for site-specific restoration work. They are: Lancaster County, PA; the Eastern Shore of MD; and the Shenandoah Valley in VA. Each area is creating pollution through sediment, nitrogen, or phosphorus loadings to the Bay.

The Coal Country Hang-Out Youth Center is designed to offer programs needed to counteract the devastation experienced by families in a geographically isolated and economically deprived area. The goals of the Center are to provide affordable and accessible child care to all families in our community, support families in the promotion of healthy behaviors among their children, and foster community-wide prevention of negative behavior among our youth.

This grant will assist in the Eastern Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation’s (EPCAMR) education and outreach efforts to state-wide regional environmental nonprofit organizations, PA Conservation Districts, community watershed associations impacted by abandoned mine lands. EPCAMR will also reach out to Legislative District Directors and Program Assistants of our House of Representatives and our US Senators, using an innovative geographic information system Mapping Tool created by EPCAMR Staff.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership along with the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy and DEP South Central Office is holding a Juniata River Basin Planning meeting. The purpose of this all-day meeting is to bring together the County Conservation District manager, watershed specialists, and Bay technicians within the watershed to discuss the updated Chesapeake Bay Tributary Strategy Plans that each county must submit and how the implementation goals outlined in these plans can be met.

North Central Pennsylvania (NCPA) is home to the headwaters for the Allegheny, Genesee, and Susquehanna Rivers. There are six volunteer watershed associations in this area and all of them are working independently to improve the streams of the rural area of NCPA. This project seeks to bring Dr. David Allan, a National Stream Ecology Expert, to NCPA to interact with the leadership and membership of these watershed associations, as well as present a keynote address entitled “What You Need to Know about Streams” to association members and the general public.

This grant will cover some of the PA Federation of Sportsmen’s Clubs (PFSC) costs associated with significantly advancing efforts to get the federal SMCRA Abandoned Mine Land Fund (AML) re-authorized. PFSC’s goal is to obtain substantial and direct support for AML reauthorization from individual hunting clubs and hunters across PA. Support will be in the form of individual letters, emails, and phone calls to elected federal official asking that the essential fund and fee structure be retained so that PA’s watersheds – our fishing streams, rivers, and lakes – will have higher water quality. The work will be handled by a qualified intern.
properties.grant_name: Costs Associated with SMCRA AML Re-authorization

properties.grant_description: The 4th Annual Pennsylvania Land Conservation Conference will act as a vehicle to expand offerings to the farmland preservation community. This grant would facilitate our opening the conference to county agricultural land preservation board members and staff, who we believe could benefit greatly from better information on conservation matters. It would also assist the PA Land Trust Association in including programming on the Conservation Resource and Enhancement Program (CREP) and riparian buffers.

“The Pennsylvania Association of Environmental Educators unites, supports, and inspires individuals to be stewards of our environment.” The plan for this year’s conference is to expand our reach beyond environmental education. We want to bring people together from a broader range of environmental groups and become the professional organization for people in all fields of environmental education, be it classroom, parks, nature centers, agencies, watershed groups, or business and industry.

This year’s conference is titled, “Our Watersheds at Risk: Protecting Water Quality, Quantity, and Stream Access” and targets grassroots organizations, watershed and sportsmen’s groups, and other environmentally active people. It will compliment our earlier conferences, which dealt with streamside buffers, water chemistry, in-stream habitat, biodiversity, and stormwater runoff. This year we will cover both proactive and reactive methods to address critical areas of concern in water quality and quantity and public access to our waterways for recreation. Participation at this year's event is expected to reach nearly 300 attendees.

Abandoned mines have left a detrimental legacy on Pennsylvania’s environment, economy, and quality of life. Countless communities across the state suffer from the blight that these sites create, the safety hazards they pose, and the acidic runoff they generate. Our goal is to ensure the restoration of areas affected by mining pollution in order to protect the environment and public health. Our strategy is to inform citizens about these problems and involve them in contacting our elected officials and urging them to take action.
No description in file.

The PA Organization for Watersheds and Rivers (POWR) is an important partner in re-authorization of the fund, used by watershed associations to address abandoned mine sites. Previously, the Foundation for PA Watersheds has been successful in securing increases for the state of Pennsylvania by working with the Appropriations Committee in Washington, DC. Reauthorization is a much bigger task and will hopefully include the provision for mandatory spending without having to go through the Appropriations Committee each year.

The Somerset Conservation District is developing a bio-energy project that will utilize hybrid poplar trees to improve the water quality in the watersheds of Somerset County. The intent is to plant a few plots where stock seedlings can be grown and harvested, allowing a large number of acres to be planted with these fast growing trees for future use. We are proposing to plant a large acreage of abandoned mine lands, which have not quite succeeded in establishing complete vegetative growth, then harvest these trees for fuel or other valuable products. The management of this potential fuel source encourages greater biodiversity and improves local environmental stewardship. A substantial amount of marginal land can be put into productive use by growing energy crops. Ultimately, we hope to develop this project into a clean source of renewable energy either from the direct burning or the conversion of the wood to be used as methanol for a fuel source.

The purpose of this grant is to develop a “Cost/Benefit Analysis” simulation methodology to determine the “social (economic) value of water” located in karst terrain groundwater aquifers – i.e., the price of water and the assessment of these property rights.
properties.project_description: This report focused on threats to groundwater in a karst geologic area.

properties.grant_description: The purpose of this year’s West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium is to provide a forum for the exchange of information and ideas regarding the cleanup of abandoned mine drainage (with the primary focus on the West Branch Susquehanna watershed), as well as to continue the momentum for the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Initiative.
properties.grant_name: West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium II

properties.grant_description: The theme for the 5th Annual Westmoreland Earth Day is “Happy Earth Day Birthday” and will celebrate the gifts the earth has given to us. The mission of this year’s event is to demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources. This event is held at St. Vincent College. The Westmoreland Conservation District and the Western PA Conservancy are very involved in the planning of this event.
The use of this destination site has resulted in the need to upgrade water lines and wastewater facilities. This grant will facilitate the planning process.

The Johnstown River Festival is an annual outreach/awareness event for the public regarding the state of our regional waterways. The Stonyceek-Conemaugh River Improvement Project (SCRIP) has, for years, held a “FUNraiser” event created to have fun and educate the public about ongoing conservation and remediation efforts. The SCRIP board, along with the Westsylvania Heritage Corporation, has decided to take this festival to the next level by bringing it to the biggest town in the watershed and inviting a greater variety of partners. It is our hope that we will be able to make this a premier annual event for the community as they learn about our rivers in an enjoyable family atmosphere.

Scotia Barrens is not only home to numerous threatened and endangered plant and animal species, but it is also a refuge for these communities from the increasing sprawl of State College. Concern exists that development within this area will degrade Big Spring, as source of water for numerous municipalities including Bellefonte and ultimately diminish flows within the Spring Creek watershed. The project will work closely with the PA Game Commission and property owners to purchase of ease lands adjacent to the barrens. The Clearwater Conservancy (Conservancy) would also work to develop recreational trail maps for the barrens indicating how citizens should access, use, and promote stewardship of this unique game lands. Additionally, the Conservancy would develop a public outreach/education brochure to assist local property owners in understanding the importance of the barrens.
properties.project_benefits: This proposal is a sound example of a proactive approach by the community to protect an important historical, cultural, and environmental resource. By doing do, numerous plant and animal communities are protected, as well as the water supply of countless residents around the Bellefonte area.

properties.grant_description: “In Their Own Words” is a collection of stories told by fifteen Pennsylvania landowners who have made the conservation choice. This publication serves as an educational tool for local organizations to inform landowners of the benefits and process of protecting family lands and preserving precious farmland, woodlands, streams, and wetlands. It is designed so that any organization in the state can comfortably use it as their own.

The Pennsylvania Statewide Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation is held for the benefit of watershed groups throughout PA. This year’s conference is themed “Back to Basics” and it will provide many workshops on important subjects such as passive treatment, development of community partners, and technological water monitoring support through Geographic Information Systems and databases. This grant will help maximize the conference’s reach to watershed volunteers by keeping the attendee costs low.

This grant helped with the development of a display board with pictures of the Sagamore, Permapress, and Kalp Projects. Working sequentially on 11 main discharges, the Mountain Watershed Association will address 97% of the abandoned mine drainage impacts in the Indian Creek watershed. Their logical and well-planned approach is a model for other groups to follow.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership 6th Annual Sojourn is an educational and fun canoe and kayak journey celebrating the beautiful sections of the Juniata River system - the Frankstown Branch, the Little Juniata, and the Raystown Branch - as well as the natural, cultural, and historical resources of the Juniata Watershed.

This grant will support the Volunteer Appreciation Picnic for the more than 200 citizen volunteers who have dedicated their precious free time to both Natural Biodiversity and the Kiski-Conemaugh Stream. This year’s picnic theme is “From Possibility to Actuality” and the theatre-style program will recognize “The Cast” of the work that has been done this year.

properties.project_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team focuses its attention on two primary programs – Water Monitoring and Environmental Education. Through the Water Monitoring Program the Stream Team provides technical assistance to smaller watershed associations, county conservation districts, and similar organizations. The Stream Team has also trained over 40 citizens volunteers and, together collected nearly 600 water samples from numerous abandoned mine discharges, twelve AMD treatment systems, and several streams impacted by AMD.
properties.project_name: Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team Technical Assistance Program
properties.grant_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team focuses its attention on two primary programs – Water Monitoring and Environmental Education. Through the Water Monitoring Program the Stream Team provides technical assistance to smaller watershed associations, county conservation districts, and similar organizations. The Stream Team has also trained over 40 citizens volunteers and, together collected nearly 600 water samples from numerous abandoned mine discharges, twelve AMD treatment systems, and several streams impacted by AMD.

This grant helped facilitate the creation of a planting plan to augment an existing riparian buffer into a natural stream channel design along the Yellow Breeches on the Messiah College campus. In addition, two rain gardens were included in the plan to intercept and slow stormwater flowing off of the tennis courts and the nearby parking area. A Computer Aided Drafting file was also developed for the implementation of the restoration work for Phase II of the project. Permit applications were also secured as a result of this grant. Sediment flowing into the Chesapeake Bay is one of the big issues for the Bay and can be addressed locally in a site-specific way.
properties.project_name: Yellow Breeches Stream Restoration Project at Messiah College
properties.project_description: This grant helped facilitate the creation of a planting plan to augment an existing riparian buffer into a natural stream channel design along the Yellow Breeches on the Messiah College campus. In addition, two rain gardens were included in the plan to intercept and slow stormwater flowing off of the tennis courts and the nearby parking area. A Computer Aided Drafting file was also developed for the implantation of the restoration work for Phase II of the project. Permit applications were also secured as a result of this grant.

properties.grant_description: A lack of understanding exists among elected officials and the conservation community about the overall expansiveness of the abandoned mine lands (AML) problem in the state. Education and outreach are necessary to put the problem into a proper perspective and to gain support for re-authorization of the AML Fund. The Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation (EPCAMR) proposes to continue work that has been done to quantify Abandoned Mine Reclamation throughout PA by displaying existing data in a visual, geospatial model.
properties.project_benefits: Re-authorization of the AML Fund is essential for the continued rehabilitation of Pennsylvania’s Abandoned Mine Lands and their associated impacts.

properties.project_description: Loyalhanna Watershed Association has completed a watershed assessment and restoration plan with Western Pennsylvania Conservancy’s Watershed Assistance Center. In this plan, Crabtree Creek was identified as the single largest water quality impact in the entire watershed. Pollution sources to the watershed include sewage, abandoned mine drainage, agricultural waste, and some stream encroachment and urbanization. This project addresses the feasibility of integrating a sewage treatment plant, an AMD reclamation site, and a bio-gas plant.
properties.grant_description: Loyalhanna Watershed Association has completed a watershed assessment and restoration plan with Western Pennsylvania Conservancy’s Watershed Assistance Center. In this plan, Crabtree Creek was identified as the single largest water quality impact in the entire watershed. Pollution sources to the watershed include sewage, abandoned mine drainage, agricultural waste, and some stream encroachment and urbanization. This project addresses the feasibility of integrating a sewage treatment plant, an AMD reclamation site, and a bio-gas plant.

Nine Mile Run is working to complete a reevaluation of its existing guidance documents. This includes updating a Watershed Restoration Plan, extracting and creating user-friendly information from their local Rivers Conservation Plan, finalizing their new Strategic Plan and organizing past-collected watershed data. The overall goal of this project is to provide a comprehensive report on the watershed’s recovery over the past five years and to engage the public in forums that will enhance their understanding of the watershed’s problems and gain their input for moving forward.
properties.project_name: State of Nine Mile Run Watershed
properties.grant_name: State of Nine Mile Run Watershed

properties.project_description: The Audenreid AMD passive treatment system went on-line in December 2005. At the time of installation, rising fuel costs prohibited the purchase of the total quantity of limestone needed to meet design specifications. This grant helped leverage additional funds towards project completion and pay for limestone needed to effectively raise the pH and buffering capacity of the water.
properties.project_name: Supplemental Limestone for an AMD Treatment System in the Catawissa Creek Watershed
properties.grant_description: The Audenreid AMD passive treatment system went on-line in December 2005. At the time of installation, rising fuel costs prohibited the purchase of the total quantity of limestone needed to meet design specifications. This grant helped leverage additional funds towards project completion and pay for limestone needed to effectively raise the pH and buffering capacity of the water. Contingencies are often most accounted for in larger agency funded projects. This type of grant is core to the mission of the Foundation for PA Watersheds - insuring improved water quality throughout the state.

This grant will contribute to the development of a communications strategy undertaken by PennFuture for the Abandoned Mine Land Fund. The work will include consultation, production of communications/media pieces, and participation in conference calls.
properties.project_name: Dev. Com. Strategy relative to Fed AMLFund
properties.grant_name: Communication Strategy Relative to the AML Fund

properties.project_benefits: This project will result in the further stabilization of 300 feet of Peters Creek as well as educate students from the West Jefferson Hills School District and area residents about watershed issues and the importance of maintaining riparian buffer zones along our waterways.
properties.grant_description: Increased runoff from highways and urbanization are causing downcutting and lateral cutting of Peters Creek. These erosional forces are causing increased sedimentation and bank instability. Working with Allegheny County and local officials, the Peters Creek Watershed Association, the West Jefferson Hills School District, and through the recommendations of an engineer, the PA Resource Council will plant a 25 foot wide by 300 foot long riparian buffer along Peters Creek.
project_participants: The Earned Income Tax Credit Program

properties.grant_description: Development in the Slab Cabin Run watershed has impacted the natural flooding sequence. Impermeable surfaces, development runoff, and the expansion of highway systems are contributing rapid runoff to the stream. Altered flow has led to increased contaminate transport, reduced retention as the stream has become separated from its floodplain, stream incising , increased erosion, increased flooding, and degradation of the riparian zone. The proposed Natural Stream Channel Design will restore 16 acres of wetlands and 600 linear feet of stream channel.

Project Grass has been a conservation tool for farmers for more than a decade and has primarily been used on beef cattle farms. With new public consciousness about where food originates and how it is raised, grass based dairying and the inclusion of sheep, poultry, and horses are the new emphasis of Project Grass. The goal of this organization is to expand the number of farms enrolled in Project Grass in order to convey the value of watershed preservation as on on-farm practice, utilizing central watering sources for livestock, and promoting better use of forage while protecting stream water quality.

This project will emulate the successful Watershed Minutes Project which showcased the efforts of local watershed groups and environmental leaders. The Allegheny Front is Western PA’s only local environmental affairs radio program. This grant will provide four interviews/segments from watershed groups as well as four interviews and subsequent segments from experts in the field of watershed issues.

The Shamokin Creek Restoration Alliance (SCRA), in partnership with the Northumberland County Conservation District (NCCD), is constructing passive treatment systems that will abate the Corbin Mine discharge which flows into Shamokin Creek. The SCRA has acquired ownership of the land proposed for treatment from Eastern Industries. SCRA will install security fencing around the site, as per township directive. This grant will help to complete treatment system construction.

The Brinkerton mine discharge is the largest in the Sewickley Creek Watershed and one of the largest in Western PA. Treatment of this site presents many challenges due to limited area, size of the discharge, and a number of upwellings within the adjacent existing wetland. After extensive testing and evaluation an active/passive design by Skelly and Loy, Inc. was chosen as they believe it will produce the most cost-effective and efficient solution.

The purpose of this award is to utilize recovered materials in a local watershed for green building design. The idea is to utilize local materials with a high insulation value to cut down on utility costs. For durability and aesthetics, iron oxide pigment was used to color the concrete floor.

The intent of this natural stream channel design is to creatively use boulder placement to effectively add habitat diversity in order to facilitate an increase in trout population and macroinvertebrate species. Local TU chapters tackle a multiplicity of restoration projects which enhance local waterways. When aggregated, these sites add up to great improvements in a watershed.

“Black Diamonds: Mountaintop Removal and the Fight for Coalfield Justice” was released by Catherine Pancake for 90-minute work-in-progress screenings in March 2005. “Black Diamonds” tells the story of mountaintop coal surface mining in Appalachia, ant the practice’s effects on the environment and local communities. The film follows local citizen activists as they work to stop or mitigate the serious and traumatic effects of the enormous industrial mine sites and their communities.
properties.project_description: “Black Diamonds: Mountaintop Removal and the Fight for Coalfield Justice” was released by Catherine Pancake for 90-minute work-in-progress screenings in March 2005. “Black Diamonds” tells the story of mountaintop coal surface mining in Appalachia, ant the practice’s effects on the environment and local communities. The film follows local citizen activists as they work to stop or mitigate the serious and traumatic effects of the enormous industrial mine sites and their communities.

properties.project_name: 2006 PA Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation
properties.grant_description: This marks the eighth consecutive year for the Conference which throughout has been a cooperative effort among many groups and agencies working together to improve the environment. The Eastern and Western Pennsylvania Coalitions for Abandoned Mine Reclamation, over the years have been very proud  to co-coordinate and convene and host the dozens of state-wide environmental resource agencies from the State, Federal, County, and local level. These conferences promote information technology exchanges and transfer of vital information that will help all of PA to reclaim its abandoned mine lands and restore streams and rivers impacted by AMD.
properties.project_description: This marks the eighth consecutive year for the Conference which throughout has been a cooperative effort among many groups and agencies working together to improve the environment. The Eastern and Western Pennsylvania Coalitions for Abandoned Mine Reclamation, over the years have been very proud  to co-coordinate and convene and host the dozens of state-wide environmental resource agencies from the State, Federal, County, and local level. These conferences promote information technology exchanges and transfer of vital information that will help all of PA to reclaim its abandoned mine lands and restore streams and rivers impacted by AMD.

properties.grant_description: The purpose of this grant is to help further watershed-based information as it relates to green building principles. The Pittsburgh regional office provides consulting services to individuals and local businesses that wish to save on utilities by investing in green technologies.
properties.project_name: Furthering Watershed-Based Info as it Relates to Green Building Principles

properties.grant_description: At the request of the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, the Independence Conservancy will prepare an application for a Rivers Conservation Plan on Raccoon Creek.
properties.project_name: DCNR Rivers Conservation Plan for Raccoon Creek
properties.project_description: This grant helped support the development of the Raccoon Creek Rivers Conservation Plan.
properties.grant_name: DCNR Rivers Conservation Plan for Raccoon Creek

properties.grant_description: The Mountain Watershed Association looks to hire an intern for a Cumulative Hydrologic Impact Assessment. Job responsibilities would include research, compilation, and coordination of hydrologic information. Interns can be very useful in gathering data for the preliminary steps toward accessing Foundation and agency restoration grants.
properties.project_name: Intern for a Cumulative Hydrologic Impact Assessment
properties.project_description: Research, compile, and coordinate hydrologic information.

properties.grant_description: In order to counter the temptation of state and local officials to begin appropriating funds to inadvisable flood control structures, the PA Organization for Watersheds and Rivers would like to draw together watershed advocates to consider conducting a public education campaign in PA. The first step would be to convene a meeting of watershed representatives to discuss the problem and a possible campaign strategy to be pursued by a coalition of groups. This grant will facilitate the initial meeting and implementation strategy.

The tour showcases successful projects that represent the four key elements of the council's Area Plan: land management, land conservation, community development, and water management. The chosen watershed for the tour was in the Broad Top, where their watershed associations are working cooperatively on all four principles.
properties.project_name: Tour bus for RC&D Council Meeting
properties.grant_name: Tour bus for RC&D Council Meeting

properties.grant_description: The 5th Annual Ohio River Watershed Celebration will focus on promoting watershed stewardship, energy conservation, education and outreach, providing networking opportunities among diverse community interests and encouraging the continual recovery of the Ohio River Watershed. When touring a length of the Allegheny, the Monogahela, or the Ohio, site-specific restoration sites are described, as well as Pittsburgh's industrial past.

Coalbed methane (CBM) is primarily methane gas trapped within coal seams. When plant material is converted into coal, methane gas is created. This gas is bonded to the coal surface by pressure from overlying rock, soil and the surrounding water table. CBM can be extracted from coal seams and used for energy. If property owners don’t own the coal rights under their land, they don’t own the CBM and are not entitled to any royalties for CBM produced under their property. This grant will go towards the production of a fact sheet that informs residents of Fayette, Greene, and Washington counties on general coalbed methane and landowner rights.
properties.grant_name: Coalbed Methane Fact Sheet and Brochure

properties.grant_description: The Chesapeake Bay Funders Network is dedicated to providing opportunities for grantmakers to network, exchange information, and partner on protecting and restoring the health of the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed. Cover crops in Pennsylvania and streambank fencing in Virginia are two examples of on-the-ground project funded by this group. This grant is for dues and convening of the group.
properties.project_description: The Chesapeake Bay Funders Network is dedicated to providing opportunities for grantmakers to network, exchange information, and partner on protecting and restoring the health of the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed.

properties.grant_description: The TCCCC is an all-volunteer organization. They hold an annual membership drive, seek donations to help fund their environmental scholarship program, and sponsor fundraisers such as raffles and food and beverage sales. This grant will help cover the costs associated with printing 500 brochures detailing their efforts to reclaim the Upper Tioga River Watershed and the cost to host their website for one year.

In accordance to Natural Biodiversity’s 2004 Southern Alleghenies RC&D Riparian Invasive Plant Initiatives Measure, the next-step action items are: continuing the demonstration of control techniques, developing and incorporating early detection and rapid response system, incorporating a project partner and citizen volunteers who monitor encroaching species and to respond to new infestations (“weed watcher” program), assessing riparian areas, and developing an initial invasive species management plan for the Upper Juniata.

This project is to support a Resource Recovery demonstration. It is well known that iron pigments recovered from AMD are valuable to the building industry. Its applications range from wood stains to concrete color enhancers. This project will further illustrate the beneficial use of iron oxides and show that they have no structural impact on concrete.

The Pennsylvania Environmental Council proposes to prepare a Rivers Conservation Plan for the Catawissa Creek Watershed located in Columbia, Luzerne, and Schuylkill Counties. The Rivers Conservation Plan, through an extensive public involvement process will address environmental, cultural, and natural resource issues within the watershed and make locally relevant recommendations for preservation or restoration of environmental integrity to the watershed based upon public input and information gathered during the course of the project. These plans are essential in order to apply for agency restoration grants.
project_participants: PA Department of Conservation and Natural Resources
Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation

properties.grant_description: This grant will contribute to the development of a communications strategy undertaken by PennFuture for the Abandoned Mine Land Fund. The work will include consultation, production of communications/media pieces, and participation in conference calls. PennFuture is strategic in placement of op-ed pieces in Congressional districts throughout the state.

The purpose of this grant is to help offset the costs of extra printings for the summer and fall issues of PA Project Grass 2005 Magazines and the organization's Statewide Conference and Grazing Field Farm Tour.
properties.project_name: PA Project Grass 2005 Magazine and Conference

properties.grant_description: The Friends of Raystown Lake would like to benefit from the help of an AmeriCorps member to support important environmental improvement projects. Among concerns of Friends of Raystown Lake is the overpopulation of deer in the forest around the lake, degrading the understory to the point where there has been a change in tree species. The group is also working on a Chestnut tree nursery in order to provide a site for blight resistant trees in the national effort by the American Chestnut Foundation.

This grant helped Audubon Pennsylvania complete the distribution of “Managing White-Tailed Deer in Forest Habitat and Ecosystem Perspective: Pennsylvania Case Study,” a report of the Deer Management Forum convened by Audubon PA and the PA Habitat Alliance. As Pennsylvania has gone through the lengthy and costly process of having its state forests certified as sustainable, it is important to understand the impacts an over-abundant deer population has on re-growth.

Last year, attendance at the Westmoreland Earth Day reached 2,000 participants. Attendance at this year's Earth Day is expected to increase by another 1,000 participants. This year's event will demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources.
Grant was awarded for the purpose of reviewing of project specific permitting related to the clean up of Toby Creek.

This award was provided to evaluate seven systems for which the WPWP leveraged money.  The study included evaluation of structural integrity of the systems, O&M, overall operations, chemicals, and macroinvertebrate data collection.  This data was then compiled into a report for the Program and gave an in-depth look into the success of operation of AMD treatment systems.

This on-going preservation effort is planning to begin a sub-set of activities called “French Creek Ecotours."  The intent is to purchase the assets of a local outfitter and to combine the project’s educational activities with recreational opportunities.  The emphasis is quality, not quantity, but nevertheless it is expected to service around 1,000 individuals per year.  A French Creek Sojourn is planned for June starting in Erie County and ending in Franklin, Pennsylvania.  At that point, after traveling over 70 miles, the French Creek joins the Allegheny River and it is here that the PA Environmental Council’s and the Alleghenies Watershed Network will continue an organized float on the Allegheny.   Once again, it is anticipated that the project will work with farmers and landowners to assist in the implementation of BMP’s.  A Growing Greener Grant for $180,000 was received for this purpose.  Activities include streambank fencing and the use of many volunteers for the removal of exotic plant species along the streambanks.

The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy, Canaan Valley Institute, and various small watershed associations are working on a community based site for the composting of livestock manure.  The proposed site is the Morrison’s Cove valley near Martinsburg, PA where several 400 cow dairy herds are located.  With intensive agriculture being regulated by the EPA’s TMDL process, (Total Maximum Daily Loads) there is the need to export nutrients out of certain watersheds.  The idea of the group is to convene the stakeholders and to set up a community site for composting, needing a carbon source from municipal clippings, where the manure could be dried, composted and sold.  In order to comply with current regulations, the composting site must be less than five acres.  The purpose of the grant is to convene the stakeholders.
